bibl.title: Letter from Harry M. Carroll to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 9, 1926

div1.p: Carroll discusses plans to make Walter Reed's birthplace a national shrine. He receives permission from Emilie Lawrence Reed to mention the pension debate in his magazine article.

div1.head: Letter from Harry M. Carroll to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 9, 1926
div1.opener:
Harry M. Carroll
Lawyer
Donna, Texas July 9, 1926.
Mrs. Walter Reed,
Blue Ridge Summit, Pa.
Dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
Thank you for the permission you kindly gave me in your letter to mention
the matter of your pension in a projected majazine article. I will send you
a copy of the article when published.

Yes, I have read Paul De Kruif's book and admired it very much. I felt,
however, that the author did not treat his subject with the dignity it merited.
In that respect it fell much below Mr. Sullivan's “Our Times,” which I con-
sider to be one of the most notable books of the century.

I am afraid we shall have to be constantly prodding the committee that
has in charge the raising of funds to convert Walter Reed's birthplace into a
national shrine. A New York friend of mine, a physician of ability and pres-
tige, is of the same opinion and between us we are attempting to devise some
way to get action without treading on anyone's toes.
With best wishes for a pleasant summer, I am,
